All week long, News Channel 3 will provide tips on how you can prepare for an emergency.What's the weather?Do you have a plan?A debate of two tales: Pro-life v. pro-choice rallies continue in downtown Grand Rapidsby Maria Serrano | News Channel 3Sun, May 15th 2022 at 8:42 PMUpdated Sun, May 15th 2022 at 11:43 PMHundreds of pro-choice protesters gather outside Grand Rapids City Hall on Saturday. (WWMT/Maria Serrano)KALAMAZOO, Mich. — Hundreds of women and men showed their support for abortion rights outside Grand Rapids City Hall on Saturday.Protest are happening across the country after a recent leaked draft opinion uncovered the Supreme Court’s apparent opposition to Roe v. Wade.The divisive abortion rights issues were also being reflected in Grand Rapids.Pro-choice protesters were on one side of city hall, and pro-life protesters on another.There were only a few counter protesters from a collective of churches, compared to the hundreds rallying in support of abortion rights.Pro-choice protesters said abortion should be a woman’s choice, not the government’s business.“I don’t believe that, that’s something that should be taken away and something that should be in the hands of men who aren’t living our life every day,” Stephanie Meyer said.The crowds said the right to have an abortion shouldn’t be up for discussion or debate.“I feel like there’s so many bigger issues in the world, so why are we focusing on putting laws on women’s bodies,” Alyssa Waid said.  “There’s a pandemic, a war, formula shortage right as we speak.”A pro-life crowd at the rally said they disagreed with abortion.“We have to love all people not just people who are born, we have to be consistent about that,” said Jordan, who did not reveal his last name.Jordan and his group said abortion is murder, and they attended the rally to bring the gospel to pro-choice protestors.“Hoping that they will receive the lord Jesus Christ and be saved, we care about them,” Jordan said.“Don’t choose death, choose life,” Derek said.Keith Arteaga said he spent his Saturday with his family at the rally.“I’ve got a daughter that’s of reproductive age and I’d be horrified if she had a pregnancy that she didn’t want and the government forced to go through nine months of bodily and hormonal change,” Arteaga said.Arteaga said the personal beliefs of the opposite side are fine for their own purposes, but it shouldn’t be forced upon other people.“Even people that believe in it, it’s still a very difficult and traumatic choice,  but they should still have that choice,” Arteaga said. “That shouldn’t be decided by somebody else.”The Supreme Court’s ruling was not expected until June or early July.Follow Maria Serrano on Facebook and Twitter.
